message_1: A cylindrical tank with a diameter of 2 meters is filled with water up to a height of 5 meters. A small hole is then made at the bottom of the tank. Determine the velocity of the water exiting the hole and the volume of water discharged after 30 seconds. (Assume the hole is very small compared to the tank size and neglect any losses due to friction or viscosity.)
message_2:
To determine the velocity of the water exiting the hole, we can use Torricelli's theorem, which states that the speed of efflux of a fluid under the force of gravity through an orifice is v = sqrt(2gh), where v is the velocity of the fluid, g is the acceleration due to gravity (approximately 9.81 m/s²), and h is the height of the fluid above the orifice.

In this case, the height of the water in the tank is 5 meters, so we have:

v = sqrt(2 * 9.81 * 5)
v ≈ sqrt(98.1)
v ≈ 9.9 m/s

So, the velocity of the water exiting the hole is approximately 9.9 m/s.

Now, to determine the volume of water discharged after 30 seconds, we need to know the area of the hole. Since the hole is very small compared to the tank size, we can assume that the flow rate of the water is constant. The flow rate (Q) can be calculated as the product of the area of the hole (A) and the velocity of the water (v):

Q = A * v

We don't have the area of the hole, so we can't calculate the exact volume of water discharged. However, if we had the area of the hole, we could calculate the volume of water discharged after 30 seconds as follows:

Volume = Q * time
Volume = A * v * time

Where time is 30 seconds.
